neighbors.name: Jason Thornock & Tracy Thornock
neighbors.claims: Jason and Tracy Thornock are third-generation ranchers in the Cokeville area of Lincoln County, Wyoming [Inside Climate News](https://insideclimatenews.org/news/14122025/cokeville-wyoming-ranch-scale-solar/). They have actively pursued on-site renewable energy, including applying for an $868,000 federal grant to build a 648-kilowatt solar array and supporting state legislation to expand net metering for ranch-scale solar systems [Inside Climate News](https://insideclimatenews.org/news/16032025/wyoming-rooftop-solar-net-metering-energy-independence/) [WyoFile](https://wyofile.com/rancher-backed-solar-power-bill-loses-glimmer-with-amendments/). Jason Thornock testified to state lawmakers that Rocky Mountain Power’s actions nearly bankrupted his ranching business, and he later lost a court battle over those utility disputes which left him paying the company’s legal fees [Inside Climate News](https://insideclimatenews.org/news/14122025/cokeville-wyoming-ranch-scale-solar/) [Justia](https://law.justia.com/cases/wyoming/supreme-court/2016/s-15-0108.html).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage through a respected fellow rancher or trusted community leader. Emphasize how the project can help sustain their family ranch for future generations while allowing local input and control, aligning with their values of independence and legacy.

citations.title: Wyoming Ranchers Hoping Solar Can Lower Costs Say Utilities and the State Stand in Their Way

citations.claim: They have actively pursued on-site renewable energy, including applying for an $868,000 federal grant to build a 648-kilowatt solar array
citations.title: Wyoming Rooftop Solar Net Metering Energy Independence

citations.claim: supporting state legislation to expand net metering for ranch-scale solar systems
citations.title: Rancher-backed solar power bill loses glimmer with amendments

citations.title: Thornock v. PacifiCorp, 2016 WY 93

neighbors.name: G & D Properties LLC
neighbors.claims: G & D Properties LLC is a Wyoming limited liability company registered to Shawn Thornock, with a principal address in Cokeville, Wyoming ([wyobiz.wyo.gov](https://wyobiz.wyo.gov/Business/FilingDetails.aspx?eFNum=241127022122024208155055022090029049015163105053)). The entity appears to be a land-holding vehicle for the Thornock family, a long-standing local ranching family in Lincoln County ([insideclimatenews.org](https://insideclimatenews.org/news/14122025/cokeville-wyoming-ranch-scale-solar/)). Unlike reports suggesting anonymous speculative ownership, state filings identify Shawn Thornock as the registered agent ([wyobiz.wyo.gov](https://wyobiz.wyo.gov/Business/FilingDetails.aspx?eFNum=241127022122024208155055022090029049015163105053)). Family member Jason Thornock has publicly expressed support for solar development as a means to sustain the ranching operation amid high electricity costs, stating that he wants "the sun to help them survive" ([insideclimatenews.org](https://insideclimatenews.org/news/14122025/cokeville-wyoming-ranch-scale-solar/)). The Thornock Ranch actively seeks agricultural workers for cattle and hay operations ([ranchworldads.com](https://www.ranchworldads.com/classified.php?listing=41301)), confirming its status as an active agricultural entity rather than a passive speculative investment.
neighbors.influence_justification: Established local ranching family (Thornock Ranch) with active operations and public voice on energy issues.

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach the Thornock family (Shawn or Jason) directly; acknowledge their public interest in solar revenue to offset ranching costs and propose a partnership that integrates well with their cattle and hay operations.

citations.claim: Registered to Shawn Thornock with principal address in Cokeville
citations.title: Wyoming Secretary of State Filing: G & D Properties, LLC

citations.claim: Jason Thornock expressed support for solar to help the ranch survive
citations.title: Cokeville Wyoming Ranch Scale Solar

citations.claim: Thornock Ranch actively seeks agricultural workers
citations.title: Ranch World Ads: Thornock Ranch

neighbors.name: Willis Land Wyoming LLC
neighbors.claims: Willis Land Wyoming LLC is a Wyoming limited liability company registered to Jordon Willis of Cokeville, Wyoming ([wyobiz.wyo.gov](https://wyobiz.wyo.gov/Business/FilingDetails.aspx?eFNum=032001058118174029224198032113143179231183021253)). Contrary to reports of mystery ownership, the entity is the land-holding arm of the Willis Ranch, a multi-generational family operation established in the area since the late 1960s ([westernagcredit.com](https://www.westernagcredit.com/files/fencelines/pdfs/Spring_2018.pdf)). The ranch is operated by Linda Willis and her sons James, Jed, and Jordon, running approximately 1,800 head of cattle and farming malt barley and hay ([westernagcredit.com](https://www.westernagcredit.com/files/fencelines/pdfs/Spring_2018.pdf)). The family utilizes precision agriculture technology to manage crop damage and improve yields ([stotzequipment.com](https://www.stotzequipment.com/news/sustainability/sustainability-willis-ranch/)). While the entity holds land in the project vicinity, it is a functional agricultural business rather than a shell company for speculative investment.
neighbors.influence_justification: Prominent local ranching family with deep historical ties (BQ Ranch roots) and significant agricultural operations.

approach_recommendations.engage: Contact Jordon Willis directly; respect the family's long-standing stewardship of the land. Frame any proposals as complementary to their advanced agricultural practices and cattle operations rather than a buyout.

citations.claim: Registered to Jordon Willis of Cokeville
citations.title: Wyoming Secretary of State Filing: Willis Land Wyoming, LLC

citations.claim: Multi-generational family operation running 1,800 head of cattle
citations.title: Western AgCredit FenceLines: Willis Ranch

citations.claim: Utilizes precision agriculture technology
citations.title: Stotz Equipment: Sustainability at Willis Ranch

neighbors.name: Putnam Ranch LLP
neighbors.claims: Putnam Ranch LLP is a Utah-based limited liability partnership with a primary address in Randolph, Utah ([waterrights.utah.gov](https://www.waterrights.utah.gov/canalinfo/canal_owners.asp)). Public records identify Keith L. Putnam and Erma N. Putnam as trustees associated with the partnership ([weblink.lcwy.org](http://weblink.lcwy.org/WebLink/DocView.aspx?id=302065&dbid=0&repo=LincolnCounty)). The entity holds significant agricultural interests, being a top recipient of Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) payments in Rich County, Utah ([farm.ewg.org](https://farm.ewg.org/top_recips.php?fips=49033&progcode=total_cr&regionname=RichCounty,Utah)). Mortgage documents confirm the partnership owns land along the Cokeville-Utah line, indicating a cross-border ranching operation ([weblink.lcwy.org](http://weblink.lcwy.org/WebLink/DocView.aspx?id=302065&dbid=0&repo=LincolnCounty)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Large regional landholder with significant participation in federal conservation programs and cross-border property ownership.

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out to Keith L. Putnam via the Randolph, UT address. Given their heavy involvement in the Conservation Reserve Program, emphasize the project's land stewardship and soil conservation benefits.

citations.claim: Primary address in Randolph, Utah
citations.title: Utah Division of Water Rights: Canal Owners

citations.claim: Keith L. Putnam and Erma N. Putnam identified as trustees
citations.title: Lincoln County Clerk Records: Mortgage Document

citations.claim: Top recipient of Conservation Reserve Program payments
citations.title: EWG Farm Subsidy Database: Rich County, Utah

neighbors.name: Pope Cattle Refuge LLC
neighbors.claims: Pope Cattle Refuge LLC is a Wyoming limited liability company managed by Evan H. Pope and Dotty Jo Pope, who transferred land to the entity in 2013 ([weblink.lcwy.org](https://weblink.lcwy.org/WebLink/DocView.aspx?id=281734&dbid=0&repo=LincolnCounty)). Evan Pope is a local landowner who actively collaborates with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, allowing access to his property for secretive marsh bird surveys ([downloads.regulations.gov](https://downloads.regulations.gov/FWS-R8-ES-2023-0146-0002/attachment_9.pdf)). This cooperation with federal conservation efforts suggests a focus on land stewardship and wildlife habitat. The entity appears to be a family-run agricultural operation with no documented public stance on the specific solar development.
neighbors.influence_justification: Local rancher with documented ties to federal wildlife conservation programs (USFWS collaboration).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage Evan Pope by highlighting the project's environmental compatibility and potential for wildlife-friendly design. His history of cooperation with USFWS suggests he may be receptive to conservation-focused development strategies.

citations.claim: Managed by Evan H. Pope and Dotty Jo Pope
citations.title: Lincoln County Clerk Records: Quitclaim Deed

citations.claim: Collaborates with U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service for bird surveys
citations.title: USFWS Secretive Marsh Bird Survey Report

overview_summary: The sole profiled neighbor has shown support for renewable energy on their ranch and holds a strong standing in the community. This individual is a high-influence member of the area as a multi-generational rancher engaged in local and state-level issues. The neighboring landowners include two opaque LLCs and two local ranch operations. The LLCs (G & D Properties LLC and Willis Land Wyoming LLC) appear to be land investment vehicles with anonymous ownership, possibly holding land for speculation or project rights. The other neighbors – Putnam Ranch LLP and Pope Cattle Refuge LLC – are family ranch entities with deep local roots, likely focused on preserving agricultural use of their land. These differing profiles pose mixed risks: hidden LLC owners add uncertainty, while ranching families could rally local sentiment but might be assuaged through respectful engagement and incentives.
